Channels - Baltimore’s harbor is a naturally
shallow river with depths averaging
between 16 and 20 feet. To meet the
requirements of shipping, channels
must be dredged and maintained by
the private sector, the State and the
Corps of Engineers.





Cargo Facilities - Baltimore’s harbor offers a
~~~~~~~~ variety of facilities to handle the four
0.0

private of bulk cargo, dry and liquid.

Coal Storage and Export Facilities - The port has

three major and one smaller coal

export facility. Coal is brought into

the port by rail, held in the railcars

| or stored on the ground, and ship-

~ ped out by barge or by large bulk
carriers.





aritime Map











(for “shifting” (towing) seagoing ships)

Bulk Liquid Storage Facilities - Bulk I|qU|d

= products are usually stored in large
] above ground tanks which can be

] seen in a variety of locations around
=4 the harbor. The majority of the tanks
are used for storage of refined petro-
leum products. Petroleum products,
including gasoline, industrial and
home heating oil, are brought into
the port by pipeline and tanker and
redistributed by fuel trucks and
barges.

Dry Bulk Facilities - A variety of dry bulk goods
are imported and exported through
the port. Generally grain and oyster
shells are exported. The port receives
iron and specialized ores, raw sugar
“and gypsum.
